(1 comment)

We should not be adding new units, especially not ones that aren't documented in phosphor-dbus-interfaces. 

The dbus-sensor implementation should do conversion to a metric unit as appropriate (for example degreesF will not be acceptable).

Thank you for the reminder. Since I found the unit CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute) in the Value.interface.yaml, which is not a metric unit, I assumed it would be fine to add the missing units. Additionally, could you help clarify whether the following 7 units are metric: CM (Cubic Meters), CMH (Cubic Meters per Hour), CMS (Cubic Meters per Second), Liter, LPH (Liters Per Hour), LPM (Liters Per Minute), and LPS (Liters Per Second)? Do these new metric units need to be merged into the Value.interface.yaml of phosphor-dbus-interfaces first?

> Since I found the unit CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute) in the Value.interface.yaml, which is not a metric unit, I assumed it would be fine to add the missing units.

Generally we only use metric units.  CFM, I agree, is not metric but was added because everyone working with thermal controls said that is the "standard" unit of measurement in that space.

>  CM (Cubic Meters), Liter

How can you have a sensor that detects Cubic Meters or Liter?  That is a volume.  If we need to add one, we should add Liter.

> CMH (Cubic Meters per Hour), CMS (Cubic Meters per Second), LPH (Liters Per Hour), LPM (Liters Per Minute), and LPS (Liters Per Second)?

Those are all the same measurement.  It would be best to determine what industry is using for measuring liquid cooling and pick one of them.
My inquiry suggests LPM is the best bet for liquid cooling.
Thank you for your suggestion. I will modify the code to include only two units: Liter and LPM (Liters Per Minute).
For the PR of `LiquidFlowLPM` in `phosphor-dbus-interfaces`, please refer to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/75325
Do other service files do this?  They shouldn't.
Yes, other service files all require xyz.openbmc_project.EntityManager.service
New daemons should be installed in libexec.
Done.
13 lines of constructor parameters??!  Something should be refactored here.
Done.
This is something that needs to go into openbmc-build-scripts build-unit-test-docker.
Understood. I set the feature to disabled to avoid build errors caused by the libmodbus dependency not being found.

That is not something we want in the committed code though.  That just means that now all your code is uncompiled in CI.

We generally want all meson options "enabled" to get the maximal amount of CI coverage on a repository.
Could I use the External Project module to build the autotools subproject for libmodbus? I noticed in the .gitignore that files other than *.wrap are not allowed under the subprojects/ directory.

No.  Please follow the conventions used already elsewhere.

Adding a new wrapfile is acceptable but we also need to add this to openbmc-build-scripts.
I see. Thanks.
I see. Thanks.
+1.  Please do as patrick asks.
nit, remove one of the two extra lines at the end of the file.  one blank line is fine.
Most of these already are present in <limits>. Please don't create a secondary set of limits.
This map already exists in a more complete form in the utilities classes.  Please use it.
Please don't write lambdas more than a few lines.  This is called out in the coding guidelines.
Please write your classes such that forward declarations like this aren't required.
This is a lot of config, none of which is documented in your commit message or anywhere else as to what each of these things to.  Please fix that.
Why are we inventing our own queue here?  Some amount of disn around this would be good.
It seems like something like boost::asio::channel might do this same thing, but be more tested than writing our own.  Any thoughts on this?

This is going to deadlock the asio reactor while you wait for a response.  Please implement your code using the appropriate asio extensions, in this case boost::asio::ip::tcp::socket, and push the values to the modbus library.
Please try to avoid unsafe pointers like this.  If you need to share ownership, so be it, use a shared pointer.
Is there a reason to use `libmodbus` over `liblightmodbus`?  Both exist in meta-openembedded already but `liblightmodbus` is header-only which seems easier to deal with.
Initially, we chose libmodbus because mbpoll uses it. I will attempt to switch to liblightmodbus and verify its reliability.
Initially, we chose libmodbus because mbpoll uses it. I will attempt to switch to liblightmodbus and verify its reliability.

Please add the reasoning to your commit message on how the dependency was selected, and why it's required over parsing the tcp stream.  I'm sure it's fine, but please capture that in the commit message so we have it.
I wasn't asking to switch to liblightmodbus.  I was asking for an analysis on why one is better than the other for our purposes.
ACK.

I noticed that liblightmodbus is licensed under GPL-3.0, which would prevent dbus-sensors from maintaining its Apache-2.0 license. However, libmodbus is licensed under LGPL-2.1, which would not affect the original licensing of dbus-sensors.
